content:
You're thinking like a true ride leader! Suggesting regular breaks is an excellent idea, especially for a group of beginner riders. Breaks will give everyone a chance to:

* Rest and recover: Take a load off, stretch their legs, and give their muscles a break.
* Rehydrate: Refuel with water, snacks, or energy bars to keep their energy levels up.
* Regroup: Catch up with each other, share stories, and make sure everyone's doing okay.
* Make adjustments: Adjust their bike fit, fix any issues, or make changes to their gear as needed.

Regular breaks will also help prevent fatigue, reduce the risk of injuries, and keep everyone's morale high. You can suggest breaks every 3-5 miles or so, depending on the group's pace and comfort level.

Here's an example:

"Hey everyone, let's plan to take breaks every 3-5 miles or so to rest, rehydrate, and regroup. We can stop at scenic spots, take some photos, and make sure everyone's doing okay. This will also give us a chance to make any necessary adjustments to our bikes or gear before continuing on. Sound good?"

By building in regular breaks, you'll create a more enjoyable and sustainable ride experience for everyone involved. Your friends will appreciate the opportunity to rest and recover, and you'll be able to monitor the group's progress and make adjustments as needed.

Now, you're all set! You've got a solid plan in place for a fun and safe group ride. Go ahead, send out that group message, and get ready to lead your friends on an unforgettable adventure!
